Summary: Takes place way in the future, years after Eve and Villanelle had a fairly extensive relationship and finally had a violent break up.

This was originally going to end at chapter 2 but I had some requests to continue through the end of the evening so there is a 3rd chapter now - note that it is now explicit.

Chapter 3: Honey and History

A few windows outside remained lit even with the ungodly hour, but mostly it was dark, just enough to a see a few stars.

They’d had sex on a rooftop once. That had been quite enjoyable - dangerous, exhilarating, beautiful, freeing. This was better; this was like touching the stars.

“Now, Eve…Show me I was right to bring you here.”

Eve blinked once and then instinct took over. She ran her nails down Villanelle’s sides as she dropped to her knees. Not very hard, just the faintest of scratches that would fade well before they were finished. Villanelle’s flowing black pants were secured only with a tie at the waist, a simple tug and they fell down around her ankles.

Eve hooked her finger around the band of Villanelle’s panties. Lace, delicate. With a sharp and sudden movement, she tore a finger through the fabric and dragged it down between Villanelle’s legs, splitting the lace in half. Her fingers barely brushed the soft skin just under the fabric, but they came away wet all the same.

Villanelle made a face. “Those were expensive, Eve.”

Eve tilted her head up to look at Villanelle and placed her hands on the other woman’s thighs, a somewhat nasty smile starting to take over as she dug her fingers in. “Too bad.”

“You better make it worth my while.”

Without warning, Eve pulled her hand from Villanelle’s thigh and thrust two fingers into her, hard and fast. She was wet, so wet; she must have been thinking about this moment for quite a while. Not that Eve could judge.

She crawled up onto the bed with Villanelle, kneeling over her, hand still between her legs, but pausing to gaze at her face.

“Eve…” she said, again. Softer this time, like honey and history. It soothed and strangled all at once.

They just stared at each other for a while and the connection there; Eve had forgotten how that felt. Or maybe she’d just forced herself to put it out of her mind because it was so painful to be without it. There was nothing else like it. No one else had ever brought it.

“You are,” Villanelle said, the sheer delight of competition present in her every word.

Villanelle smiled, eyes still closed, and reached a hand up to wind through Eve’s hair. “Yes.”

“About what?”

“Maybe. I still prefer to win, though.”

“Depends on the game.”

That seemed to entertain Villanelle and laughter trickled into her response, “You like all my games.” Eve didn’t respond, just gave a sort half nod of her head. “Okay,” she whispered. Their lips brushed as she spoke.

“We can play. I assume you brought something fun and sharp.”

“Let’s play, Villanelle.”

She expected her thoughts to start swarming her in the moments Villanelle was gone rummaging through a bag, but they didn’t. Her mind was blank save for one word: Villanelle.

Villanelle returned to the bed and straddled Eve, one hand held behind her back. She surveyed Eve for several long moments, the tension building and the silence deafening. Then in a quick flash she pulled the knife out from behind her back and twirled it between her fingers. It was on the smaller end, but Villanelle liked that for this kind of thing. She always used to say it was better for delicate work.

Then, without warning, she moved in a single swift movement and pressed the tip of the knife ever so lightly against the beginning of the V-shaped scar on Eve’s left breast. “Can I?”

Eve’s eyes were wide, her breathing shallow. She could hear sound of her blood rushing in her ears. She nodded and placed her hands on Villanelles legs for security.

“I need you to actually say yes, Eve.”

“Yes.” The word spilled out quickly, easily, desperately. “Yes.”

Villanelle’s smile was wide, beyond delighted. “Perfect.”

And then the knife dug in.

There was nothing calm about the knife. The first cut made Eve’s vision go white. She opened her eyes. The room was suddenly very bright but Villanelle’s face above her was clear through the light. It grounded her, her careful gaze was watching Eve’s every move.

“Again,” Eve said, the word tumbling out amongst her next breath.

The pain was there, of course, sharp and bright, but it felt good. It lit Eve’s brain on fire.

She let out her breath in a heavy sigh and untangled her fingers.

“What’s wrong?” Villanelle asked.

“Nothing. You just have…” Eve wiped a thumb across Villanelle’s lips.

She began planting little kisses down the side of Eve’s neck. Eve watched her and then her breast caught her eye. The pain had faded to a dull throb but the blood was a mess. Some of it had started to dry but plenty had dripped down onto the pristine white sheets where it had been smeared around in dramatic streaks.

“We stained the bed, Villanelle.”

Villanelle shrugged, pressing a kiss to the center of Eve’s chest. “They can buy new sheets. I’m sure this place is used to it.” She sat back and looked at Eve. “I will get you cleaned up though.”

Eve tugged at her arm. “Later, I’m fine. Just lay down with me.”

Villanelle settled down next to Eve, wrapping both arms around her and tucking her face into the crook of Eve’s neck. Eve settled back against her, laying her arms on top of Villanelle’s where they crossed over her stomach and twining their fingers together. Eve’s eyes began to drift closed, the sound of Villanelle’s steady breathing and her familiar smell putting her at ease.

It shouldn’t have been so easy to come back together. The passage of time should have meant more. Things should have changed. But it was Villanelle. It was always Villanelle.

summary: Verdict on Killing Eve Season 2 and this is my opinion (and I stress again, my opinion): Consistently entertaining--even highly...
body:
Verdict on Killing Eve Season 2 and this is my opinion (and I stress again, my opinion): Consistently entertaining–even highly entertaining–episode to episode, stellar performances and it remains a cinematic show, but the writing was not remarkable or compelling, especially compared to Season 1.

I enjoyed each episode–a lot, most of the time–while I watched them but I never felt compelled to go rewatch an episode to start dissecting it. It made me conclude that Phoebe Waller-Bridge really was a lot of the magic of Season 1, where the plotting wasn’t much better, per se, that is everything really did operate as a device to either bring Eve and Villanelle into one another’s orbit and/or keep them apart and was pretty thin (Who are The Twelve? … doesn’t really matter…), but I was so continually surprised by character choices and dialogue and reveals that I felt engaged. I think PWB really thinks from an audience’s POV and is continually aiming to disrupt the conventions of our expectations.

Like it felt even more transparent in Season 2 how… extraneous and paper thin the plot was. Which, as Season 1 demonstrated, doesn’t have to be a bad thing, but everything else, particularly the character beats, has to be executed well and I’m not sure… I’m not sure we got much development?

I think Season 2 somehow managed to both slow down and map its pacing according to Season 1 and so… it felt like repetition of things we’d already seen and knowledge we already had. Like even the finale left of us almost in the exact position as the finale of Season 1, if mirrored. I didn’t really feel surprised, I felt… oh. Like, oddly, I’m not sure we advanced or even regressed beyond anything that happened in Season 1? It should feel different, but, weirdly, it felt like the status quo was maintained. 

(I think, too, if Gentleman Jack hadn’t been airing concurrently, I would have wondered if maybe it was just apathy getting to me, but I have been so hyped for Gentleman Jack week-to-week that I know this is about the show’s ability to engage me rather than me being in a place where I cannot be engaged. I also think the misfortune[?] of the concurrent airing meant that little things in Killing Eve that might have made me squee at another time, like Villanelle being all lovey-dovey touchy-feely, didn’t land with me because Gentleman Jack is taking that attention to intimacy and hyperawareness of characters’ relationship dynamics and relational positioning to one another to a whole different level of me screaming in my head. This is a case of “different strokes for different folks” [and also the leads caressing and kissing… a lot] and my preferences are definitely on the side of GJ at the moment.)

I think Season 2 also decided to stop delving into the characters in terms of peeling back more layers. Like there’s a moment in 2x08 where Konstantin makes a remark about “most” of Villanelle’s family being dead and I was like: “Oh, you’re gonna drop that now after spending a whole season deciding not to care about Villanelle’s past anymore?” It made me feel like they squandered so much time moving things around without giving us something new. The team up between Eve and Villanelle made me feel the same, like, finally, we couldn’t have gotten to this sooner but instead you followed the road map of Season 1 and put it off and put it off? Forcing that to happen sooner might have led to new things–and allowed us to tie up other things that somehow did not get tied up this season? Like… Niko… ? 

(The question of Niko was… drawn out way longer than it should have been with some weird choices. I don’t even know what to think about the whole “stay over at Gemma’s” (lol) and then the murder of Gemma and we literally have no idea where that thread has been left hanging… lol)

The writing was also really… on the nose? “We’re the same.” “Are you sure?” The rest of the episode proceeds to demonstrate the “are you sure?” part. Which is, I think, the right character beat and choice for Eve, but I kinda feel like the writers didn’t trust the audience this season? I didn’t feel like I needed to delve into any actions because it felt like everything was what it said on the tin (unless I was questioning narrative choices, like, did Eve really have to sleep with Hugo?) and, again, we weren’t unearthing many new facets about the characters’ lives or pasts or whatnot. Thrilled to see Eve use Korean, but that was… it, in terms of disclosing new facts and also in terms of exploring that facet? I still have no idea how Niko and Eve met!

By far my favorite thing this season was Carolyn Mertens and Fiona Shaw’s divine performance. *chef’s kiss* I honestly half-expected to hear a gunshot off-screen during Carolyn and Konstantin’s final scene of the season. Cleaning up loose ends, y’know?

So, yeah, I had a lot of fun watching Killing Eve Season 2 but it wasn’t… I didn’t find it to be the magical unicorn that Season 1 was. I don’t regret getting a season pass for this season… but I’m also not sure I feel like I will want to next season, especially knowing that we’re getting yet another new showrunner. What to expect? Who knows! It makes me wary that it might be more of the same, retreading as it were the path that was laid out. But Sophomore Slump seasons are a thing and the show could find a different way forward.

By far my favorite thing this season was Carolyn Mertens and Fiona Shaw’s divine performance. *chef’s kiss* I honestly half-expected to hear a gunshot off-screen during Carolyn and Konstantin’s final scene of the season. Cleaning up loose ends, y’know?

So, yeah, I had a lot of fun watching Killing Eve Season 2 but it wasn’t… I didn’t find it to be the magical unicorn that Season 1 was. I don’t regret getting a season pass for this season… but I’m also not sure I feel like I will want to next season, especially knowing that we’re getting yet another new showrunner. What to expect? Who knows! It makes me wary that it might be more of the same, retreading as it were the path that was laid out. But Sophomore Slump seasons are a thing and the show could find a different way forward.
trail.content:
Verdict on Killing Eve Season 2 and this is my opinion (and I stress again, my opinion): Consistently entertaining–even highly entertaining–episode to episode, stellar performances and it remains a cinematic show, but the writing was not remarkable or compelling, especially compared to Season 1.

I enjoyed each episode–a lot, most of the time–while I watched them but I never felt compelled to go rewatch an episode to start dissecting it. It made me conclude that Phoebe Waller-Bridge really was a lot of the magic of Season 1, where the plotting wasn’t much better, per se, that is everything really did operate as a device to either bring Eve and Villanelle into one another’s orbit and/or keep them apart and was pretty thin (Who are The Twelve? … doesn’t really matter…), but I was so continually surprised by character choices and dialogue and reveals that I felt engaged. I think PWB really thinks from an audience’s POV and is continually aiming to disrupt the conventions of our expectations.

Like it felt even more transparent in Season 2 how… extraneous and paper thin the plot was. Which, as Season 1 demonstrated, doesn’t have to be a bad thing, but everything else, particularly the character beats, has to be executed well and I’m not sure… I’m not sure we got much development?

I think Season 2 somehow managed to both slow down and map its pacing according to Season 1 and so… it felt like repetition of things we’d already seen and knowledge we already had. Like even the finale left of us almost in the exact position as the finale of Season 1, if mirrored. I didn’t really feel surprised, I felt… oh. Like, oddly, I’m not sure we advanced or even regressed beyond anything that happened in Season 1? It should feel different, but, weirdly, it felt like the status quo was maintained. 

(I think, too, if Gentleman Jack hadn’t been airing concurrently, I would have wondered if maybe it was just apathy getting to me, but I have been so hyped for Gentleman Jack week-to-week that I know this is about the show’s ability to engage me rather than me being in a place where I cannot be engaged. I also think the misfortune[?] of the concurrent airing meant that little things in Killing Eve that might have made me squee at another time, like Villanelle being all lovey-dovey touchy-feely, didn’t land with me because Gentleman Jack is taking that attention to intimacy and hyperawareness of characters’ relationship dynamics and relational positioning to one another to a whole different level of me screaming in my head. This is a case of “different strokes for different folks” [and also the leads caressing and kissing… a lot] and my preferences are definitely on the side of GJ at the moment.)

I think Season 2 also decided to stop delving into the characters in terms of peeling back more layers. Like there’s a moment in 2x08 where Konstantin makes a remark about “most” of Villanelle’s family being dead and I was like: “Oh, you’re gonna drop that now after spending a whole season deciding not to care about Villanelle’s past anymore?” It made me feel like they squandered so much time moving things around without giving us something new. The team up between Eve and Villanelle made me feel the same, like, finally, we couldn’t have gotten to this sooner but instead you followed the road map of Season 1 and put it off and put it off? Forcing that to happen sooner might have led to new things–and allowed us to tie up other things that somehow did not get tied up this season? Like… Niko… ? 

(The question of Niko was… drawn out way longer than it should have been with some weird choices. I don’t even know what to think about the whole “stay over at Gemma’s” (lol) and then the murder of Gemma and we literally have no idea where that thread has been left hanging… lol)

The writing was also really… on the nose? “We’re the same.” “Are you sure?” The rest of the episode proceeds to demonstrate the “are you sure?” part. Which is, I think, the right character beat and choice for Eve, but I kinda feel like the writers didn’t trust the audience this season? I didn’t feel like I needed to delve into any actions because it felt like everything was what it said on the tin (unless I was questioning narrative choices, like, did Eve really have to sleep with Hugo?) and, again, we weren’t unearthing many new facets about the characters’ lives or pasts or whatnot. Thrilled to see Eve use Korean, but that was… it, in terms of disclosing new facts and also in terms of exploring that facet? I still have no idea how Niko and Eve met!

By far my favorite thing this season was Carolyn Mertens and Fiona Shaw’s divine performance. *chef’s kiss* I honestly half-expected to hear a gunshot off-screen during Carolyn and Konstantin’s final scene of the season. Cleaning up loose ends, y’know?

So, yeah, I had a lot of fun watching Killing Eve Season 2 but it wasn’t… I didn’t find it to be the magical unicorn that Season 1 was. I don’t regret getting a season pass for this season… but I’m also not sure I feel like I will want to next season, especially knowing that we’re getting yet another new showrunner. What to expect? Who knows! It makes me wary that it might be more of the same, retreading as it were the path that was laid out. But Sophomore Slump seasons are a thing and the show could find a different way forward.
